bioghist.p: The Library Company of Philadelphia is an independent research library concentrating on American society and culture from the 17th through 19th centuries. It was founded in 1731 by Benjamin Franklin as a subscription library supported by its shareholders, as it is to this day. Free and open to the public, the Library Company houses an extensive non-circulating collection of rare books, manuscripts, broadsides, ephemera, and works of art.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of photographs, slides, contact sheets, transparencies, and negatives related to the Library Company of Philadelphia. Subjects include: interiors and exteriors of Library Company buildings; prints and drawings of Library Company buildings and the construction of the Locust Street buildings; early catalogues and manuscripts; exhibitions and openings; events and parties; staff members; objects and paintings; and materials used in various Library company exhibitions and publications. There are photocopies of some photographs included in the files.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
